	Not really what you're looking for by the sounds, but you could have
a test method that tests the entire XML file, and have a StringBuffer in
that method that you append a message like "test12.xml failed" to if there
is an error with any <file> entry in the XML file. Then, at the end of the
test, if there is anything in the StringBuffer, you could fail and provide
the text within the StringBuffer. No separate tests, but it does allow the
test to continue after a failure.

	-tim

-----Original Message-----
From: David Goudreau [mailto:dgoudreau@...]
Sent: Tuesday, February 04, 2003 2:18 PM
To: Junit (E-mail)
Subject: [junit] Dynamically generating test methods?


I'm creating a framework to test XML responses to our system.  Right now I
have a properties file that contains 1) every file request I want to send to
our system and 2) the xpath expressions I want to run on the XML response,
to make sure it's correct.  The properties file looks like this:

<xml_testing controldir="controlxml" requestdir="requestxml">
   <file name="test1.xml">
      <xpath expression="//FUNCTION/RESPONSE_DATA"/>
      <xpath expression="//USER"/>
   </file>
   <file name="test2.xml">
      <xpath expression="//HEADER/IP_ADDRESS"/>
   </file>
   <file name="test3.xml">
      <xpath expression="//USER/NAME"/>
      <xpath expression="//USER/ADDRESS"/>
   </file>
</xml_testing>

The problem I'm having is that I want each <file> to run as a separate test
in the JUnit framework.  Right now, even if I have 100 files that I want to
test in my properties file, the JUnit framework treats it all as one test.
I don't want test #4 to fail and then prevent the other 96 tests from
running, which is what's happening now.  Any ideas?  Thanks.
